extracted-table.table-caption: Random forest importance parameters mean minimal depth, number of nodes, accuracy decrease, Gini decrease, number of trees, times a root, and p-value), and the direction of significance for the top significant variables (p < 0.05) are shown. Two of the impulsivity scores (motor and non-planning) and 12 rsFC connections were identified as important features to classify individuals into either AUD or CTL group. The variables are sorted based on the p-values.

caption.p: Random forest importance parameters mean minimal depth, number of nodes, accuracy decrease, Gini decrease, number of trees, times a root, and p-value), and the direction of significance for the top significant variables (p < 0.05) are shown. Two of the impulsivity scores (motor and non-planning) and 12 rsFC connections were identified as important features to classify individuals into either AUD or CTL group. The variables are sorted based on the p-values.

fn.p: Acronym: BIS—Barratt Impulsiveness Scale, FC—Functional Connectivity, R—Right, L—Left, ACC—Anterior Cingulate Cortex, Amg—Amygdala, Ang—Angular Gyrus, Cdt—Caudate, DLP—Dorsolateral PFC, Hip—Hippocampus, Ins—Insula (anterior), NAc—Nucleus Accumbens, OFC—Orbitofrontal Cortex, Pal—Pallidum, PCC—Posterior Cingulate Cortex, PHG—Parahippocampal Gyrus, Ptm—Putamen, Tha—Thalamus, VTA—Ventral Tegmental Area. Key: A > C = AUD > CTL; C > A = CTL > AUD.

extracted-table.table-caption: Pearson bivariate correlations between the age of the participant and the top significant variables of the RF model. Correlation coefficient (r) and p-values (before Bonferroni correction) are provided for alcohol use disorder (AUD), control (CTL) group, and the total sample (ALL). None of the variables survived Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons. Zero-order correlations were used for each group separately (N = 30) and partial correlations controlling for group effects were used for the all sample (N = 60).

caption.p: Pearson bivariate correlations between the age of the participant and the top significant variables of the RF model. Correlation coefficient (r) and p-values (before Bonferroni correction) are provided for alcohol use disorder (AUD), control (CTL) group, and the total sample (ALL). None of the variables survived Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons. Zero-order correlations were used for each group separately (N = 30) and partial correlations controlling for group effects were used for the all sample (N = 60).

fn.p: * p < 0.05 (before Bonferroni correction); ○ Not significant after Bonferroni correction; § Based on partial correlation adjusted for group effect. Refer to Table 2 for the details of the ROIs in the FC variable.
